param.name: NoteText
param.value:
The acquisition script will center the target in the middle of the rectangular portion of the GNIRS field.
The semicircular portion of the field is below the rectangle. The template science dither patterns are centered at (p,q)=(-3,0) and are small enough to fit in the field of view of the new Y-MK, J-MK and H-MK photometric filters (see www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/imaging).

param.name: title
param.value: Acq: Imaging before standard Bright target

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The acquisition mirror used for imaging does not go into position reproducibly. For this reason, GCAL flats must be taken at night immediately after the science observations (unless the PI intends to use sky flats). Flats have been embedded in the science template for each filter.

param.name: title
param.value: Acq: Imaging after standard Bright target

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
EVERY GNIRS OBSERVATION MUST HAVE AN ASSOCIATED ACQUISITION OBSERVATION defined by the PI during the phase II process. The acquisition process is described at: www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition. This page also provides tables of suggested exposure times to AVOID SATURATION which will cause severe persistance that will affect subsequent observations.
Briefly, we distinguish four main types of acquisition method, depending on the brightness of the target (in Vega mags):
1) Very bright objects (H < 11.5): Narrow-band filter, no sky subtraction (for H < 7, the ND100X filter can be used to avoid saturation, but see the warning about filter shifts here: www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition
2) Bright objects (11.5 < H < 16): Broad-band filter, no sky subtraction
3) Faint objects (16 < H <20): Broad-band filter, sky subtraction
4) Very faint objects (H > 20): Blind offset from a nearby reference star
The OT acquisition templates use the target brightness from the PIT (if any) to choose the appropriate acquisition observation for each science observation (standard stars are assumed to use the "very bright object" type). Please double-check that this is indeed the most suitable option; for example, the PIT magnitudes for extended objects may be very different from what GNIRS sees.
The OT templates are generated with the appropriate instrument configuration. The criteria are listed below, in case changes are made by the PI. Target-specific changes may need to be made as follows:
1) In the images of the field, set the exposure time and coadds for the brightness of science target (see www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition for recommendations). If the target is extended, double, or in a crowded field, you may need to change the size or location of the sky offset from its default 2". Acquisitions normally use the H or H2 filter, but others are possible; see the above web page.
2) Make sure that blind offset acquisitions contain sky offsets if necessary (as in the "faint target" example)
3) If applicable, add a note for the observer with any special acquisition instructions. Don't forget to upload a finding chart if necessary.
GNIRS configuration:
1) In the GNIRS component: - all fields except the read mode, exposure time, and coadds should match the spectroscopy observation - "deep" well depth should be used for thermal IR acquisitions in the PAH filter - all other fields are either set in the "Sequence" or not relevant for acquisition imaging
2) In the Sequence: - in the initial slit image, the FPU and decker should match the spectroscopy configuration. The filter should only be changed if you intend to acquire the target in a filter other than H or H2. - in the final slit image, the FPU and decker should be the same as in the initial slit image, and the exposure time, coadds, and sky offset as for the images of the target field - in all steps, the read mode should be appropriate for the exposure time (see http://www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition) - if the acquisition is intended to be used for a Telluric standard, the observe class should be "Acquisition Calibration"

param.name: title
param.value: NOTE1: Exp times for Telluric standards

param.name: NoteText
param.value: Please check the exposure time for the Telluric standards using the ITC (or http://www.gemini.edu/std-star-exposure-times) to AVOID SATURATION. Persistance is very severe with the GNIRS detector and may last ~20 minutes and impact subsequent observations.

param.name: title
param.value: NOTE2: Calibrations for high spectral resolution observations

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
GCAL configurations have been updated for calibrations in the R~6000 and R~18000 modes, but not for every possible central wavelength. For central wavelengths substantially different from those given in the library templates, please add a note to your program informing your contact scientist, and we will check the flat/arc configurations ahead of taking on-sky data for your program.
Some wavelength regions contain only a few faint arc lines. In these cases it can be useful to take extra arc spectra during the day in case the fainter lines in the nighttime arcs are compromised by pattern noise (which can't be cleaned out without also removing the arc lines). Some wavelength settings may have no useful arc lines at all, in which case it will be necessary to use sky lines for wavelength calibration.
Arc spectra are not taken in the L and M bands.

param.name: title
param.value: NOTE3: Bad pixels in XD mode

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The GNIRS detector contains a few small regions of bad pixels (see www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/nirs/N20100812S0080.jpg). The bad pixels lie between the XD orders in the most heavily-used, low-resolution XD modes (0.05"/pix + 10 l/mm; 0.15"/pix + 32 l/mm). However, the exact placement of the orders in the higher-resolution modes depends on the grating central wavelength. If the presence of these bad pixels could affect your science in these modes, please advise your contact scientist as you prepare your phase II program. The CS will be able to take arc spectra that show exactly where the bad pixels will lie, and help you adjust your central wavelength to avoid them.

param.name: title
param.value: NOTE4: Differential refraction and XD mode

param.name: NoteText
param.value: Because of the large wavelength coverage of the XD modes, differential refraction can cause light to be lost from the slit in certain circumstances. If you are interested in the whole 0.9 - 2.5 um wavelength range and are using a very narrow slit and/or expect your target to be observed at high airmass, you may wish to consider observing at the mean parallactic angle: https://www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/observation-preparation/ot-details

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The initial slit image is taken in the H band filter as exposure times in the narrowband H2 filter used to image bright targets are prohibitively long for slit imaging. The images of the target field and of the target through the slit are taken in the H2 filter.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of target through slit

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The initial slit image is taken in the H band filter as exposure times in the narrowband H2 filter used to image bright targets are prohibitively long for slit imaging. The images of the target field and of the target through the slit are taken in the H2 filter combined wth the ND100X filter.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of target through slit

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The initial slit image is taken in the H band filter as exposure times in the narrowband H2 filter used to image bright targets are prohibitively long for slit imaging. The images of the target field and of the target through the slit are taken in the H2 filter.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of target through slit

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of target through slit

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of field through slit (w/ sky offset)

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This observation must contain a "Blind-offset" (reference) star which will be placed in the slit, and then the telescope will be offset to the faint science target. The reference star must be able to use the same guide star as the science target and both must have accurate coordinates. See this web page for more details:
www.gemini.edu/sciops/telescopes-and-sites/acquisition-hardware-and-techniques/acquisition-techniques
Note that the target component in the associated spectroscopy observation must be the same as that in the acquisition observation (i.e., must also include the Blind-offset reference star). See the Blind Offset group in the Complete Examples section of the GNIRS Library for an example.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of target through slit

param.name: NoteText
param.value: This template might be used for placing a long slit along the long axis of a galaxy or across a large planet.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of field through slit (w/ sky offset)

param.name: NoteText
param.value: Include this re-acquisition for observations longer than 1 hour. Update the exposure time to match the acquisition observation.

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The initial slit image is taken in the H band filter as exposure times in the narrowband H2 filter used to image bright targets are prohibitively long for slit imaging. The images of the target field and of the target through the slit are taken in the H2 filter.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Images of target through slit

param.name: title
param.value: Daytime pinhole flats for tracing spectra

param.name: NoteText
param.value: Pinhole flats are used for tracing the XD spectral orders. As with the flats and arcs embedded in the science observation, the GNIRS configuration of the pinhole flats should match that of the science observation, with the exception that the FPU should be pinhole 0.3 for the 0.15"/pix camera or pinhole 0.1 for the 0.05"/pix camera.

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
EVERY GNIRS OBSERVATION MUST HAVE AN ASSOCIATED ACQUISITION OBSERVATION defined by the PI during the phase II process. The acquisition process is described at: www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition. This page also provides tables of suggested exposure times to AVOID SATURATION which will cause SEVERE persistance that will affect subsequent observations.
Briefly, we distinguish four main types of acquisition method, depending on the brightness of the target (in Vega mags): 1) Very bright objects (H < 11.5): Narrow-band filter, no sky subtraction (for H < 7, the ND100X filter can be used to avoid saturation, but see the warning about filter shifts here: www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition) 2) Bright objects (11.5 < H < 16): Broad-band filter, no sky subtraction 3) Faint objects (16 < H <20): Broad-band filter, sky subtraction 4) Very faint objects (H > 20): Blind offset from a nearby reference star
The OT acquisition templates use the target brightness from the PIT (if available) to choose the appropriate acquisition for each science observation (standard stars are assumed to use the "very bright object" type). Please double-check that this is indeed the most suitable option; for example, the PIT magnitudes for extended objects may be very different from what GNIRS sees.
The OT templates are generated with the appropriate instrument configuration. The criteria are listed below, in case changes are made by the PI. Target-specific changes may need to be made as follows:
1) In the images of the field, set the exposure time and coadds for the brightness of science target (see www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition for recommendations). If the target is extended, double, or in a crowded field, you may need to change the size or location of the sky offset from its default. Acquisitions normally use the H or H2 filter, but others are possible; see the above web page.
2) Make sure that blind offset acquisitions contain sky offsets if necessary (as in the "faint target" example)
3) If applicable, add a note for the observer with any special acquisition instructions. Don't forget to upload a finding chart if necessary.
GNIRS configuration:
1) In the GNIRS component: - all fields except the read mode, exposure time, and coadds should match the spectroscopy observation - "deep" well depth should be used for thermal IR acquisitions in the PAH filter - all other fields are either set in the "Sequence" or not relevant for acquisition imaging
2) In the Sequence: - the read mode should be appropriate for the exposure time (see http://www.gemini.edu/sciops/instruments/gnirs/spectroscopy/acquisition) - if the acquisition is for a Telluric standard the observe class should be "Acquisition Calibration"

param.name: NoteText
param.value: The initial slit image is taken in the H band filter as exposure times in the narrowband H2 filter used to image bright targets are prohibitively long for slit imaging. The images of the target field and of the target through the slit are taken in the H2 filter combined wth the ND100X filter.

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: field Image with sky offset

param.name: title
param.value: GNIRS: Image through IFU with sky offset (undispersed)

param.name: NoteText
param.value:
This observation must contain a "Blind-offset" (reference) star which will be placed in the IFU, and then the telescope will be offset to the faint science target. The reference star must be able to use the same guide star as the science target and both must have accurate coordinates. See this web page for more details:
www.gemini.edu/sciops/telescopes-and-sites/acquisition-hardware-and-techniques/acquisition-techniques
Note that the target component in the associated spectroscopy observation must be the same as that in the acquisition observation (i.e., must also include the Blind-offset reference star). See the Blind Offset group in the Complete Examples section of the GNIRS Library for an example.
